Award.AwardTitle: New Perspectives in Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations Modeling Collective Quantum Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is devoted to the analysis of nonlinear partial differential equations arising in the mathematical description of collective quantum dynamics, with applications to, e.g., Bose-Einstein condensates. The mathematical equations under consideration will mostly be dispersive, and hence conservative, but several non-conservative (or dissipative) extensions will also be studied. By doing so, connections between equations of nonlinear Schrödinger type and complex Ginzburg-Landau type models will become apparent. In the present project the PI will: (1) study the influence of fast rotating potentials, experimentally used to create quantum vortices, on the possibility of finite time blow-up, and establish connections to recently found singular ring type solutions; (2) give a time-dependent description of vortex creation by means of adiabatic perturbation theory; (3) establish rigorous connections between nonlinear Schrödinger equations and other dispersive models; (4) explore the possibility of dispersive blow-up for the considered equations; (5) analyze the long-time behavior of solutions to Schrödinger type equations with additional nonlinear damping terms and other dissipative regularizations. The techniques to be deployed will range from numerical simulations over formal analytical methods to fully rigorous mathematical investigations based on, e.g., virial estimates, multi-scale techniques, Lyapunov-type functionals, and concentration compactness methods.


This project aims to find a rigorous mathematical description of certain collective phenomena in many-body quantum mechanics. Quantum mechanics is one of the two fundamental building blocks in modern physics and it concerns the study of mechanical systems whose dimensions are close to, or even smaller than, the atomic scale. The mathematical formulation pioneered by E. Schrödinger, P. Dirac, and J. von Neumann is to a large extent based on partial differential equations for complex-valued wave functions, which describe the state of the particles in a probabilistic interpretation. It is the solution of these equations which can be seen as one of the main driving forces in the early stages of the development of the theory. The present project lies at the intersection between the mathematical analysis of such equations and their application in theoretical physics. It will help gain a deeper mathematical understanding of the qualitative behavior of the different classes of nonlinear equations involved and their relations with each other. Answers to the questions raised will have a strong impact as proven statements in a wide range of the mathematical sciences, and can be seen as complimentary to the vast amount of non-rigorous results available in the physics literature. Most of the proposed research will be conducted through national and international collaborations with colleagues working in mathematical analysis, theoretical physics, and numerical simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Christof Sparber has completed mathematical research for his regular three-year NSF project, entitled ``New Perspectives in Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations Modeling Collective Quantum Dynamics".

This project deals with the mathematical analysis and numerical simulation of certain types of partial differential equations arising in the description of complex quantum systems. A typical example of such a system is a Bose-Einstein condensate, i.e., an ultracold gas, in which many (hundreds or even thousands of) quantum particles behave ``collectively". In certain physical parameter regimes this behavior can be described by partial differential equations of nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) type and many such equations are currently proposed and studied in the mathematics and physics literature. This project adds to this study and has produced several new results within this context. 

First, we investigated NLS type models with additional nonlinear damping terms. These terms describe complicated physical scattering processes and their resulting loss of energy on a phenomenological level. We produced a detailed mathematical investigation of the existence and long time behavior of the NLS solution for different types of scattering processes. Second, we investigated the possibility of the, so-called, "dispersive blow-up phenomenon". The latter is the result of a coalescence of small (linear) dispersive waves with different frequencies at a single space-time point at which they all constructively interfere to form a giant energy peak. Such a phenomenon has been observed, e.g., in nonlinear laser optics. The associated mathematical theory had only been rigorously understood in one spatial dimension, but we were able to prove that it is indeed possible also in higher dimenions and stable under a large variety of nonlinear perturbations. A third line of investigation concerns the semi-classical analysis of quantum dynamics using the mathematical language of ``Bohmian trajectories". These trajectories have been postulated by David Bohm in the 1950's and, even though physically controversial, they do allow for new mathematical insights into the emergence of the classical particle dynamics (or, Newton's second law) from the underlying quantum mechanical system. Our results have shown that this emergence is strongly dependent on the choice of the initial quantum state (or, wavefunction), and in general it results in a situation which is more complicated than one might naively guess from Newton's second law. Another line of investigation concerns the efficient numerical simulation of fractional NLS type models (in the full quantum, as well as in the semi-classical regime). We have developed a numerical split-step algorithm for such fractional NLS and we were able to demonstrate its strong performance in terms of numerical efficiency and high accuracy. We also used our numerical experiments to formulate several conjectures on the long-time behavior of the solution, which are out of reach of the current mathematical theory. Finally, we studied the mathematical control theory for Bose-Einstein condesates influenced by external laser fields. For a given physical target observable (such as, e.g., the desired kinetic momentum, or the center of mass of the wave function), we studied the interplay between the nonlinear effects inherent in the condensate and the energy required for the controlling laser field.

All of the results obtained are the product of several national and international collaborations with colleagues from the US, France, UK, Germany, and Italy. The scientific impact of these results is mainly in the fundamental research of mathematical quantum physics and related sciences, as well as in the mathematical theory of differential equations.
